A former work colleague told me this:
This person was in Iraq to teach the Iraqis how to use a radar, presumably the class was in Baghdad before the Gulf War. While the class was in session, a charming moustachioed and clearly important man entered the classroom and speaking perfect English addressed my colleague who was teaching the class. My colleague had absolutely no idea who this person was.
This man asked whether everyone was working hard and showing interest. My colleague innocently said everyone is working very hard, except for that person at the back (and he pointed at the person). The charming man snapped his fingers and pointed at the man at the back who was now cowering and terrified. The charming man's entourage then grabbed the terrified man and dragged him out of the classroom. The charming man thanked the teacher, apologised for the disturbance and left. Outside, there was a single gunshot heard. Everyone in the class was extra hard working from then-on. Later, a bloody mess was seen at head-height on the wall of the corridor outside.
The very charming but utterly ruthless man turned-out to be Saddam Hussein.

I would say this is definitely the case.  I am related to someone who is a union official.  He knows a congressman.  That congressman knows the president who knows most major world leaders and a good many other celebrities including in sports and entertainment.  That's only 4 degrees.   I know my niece who is a minor actress who knows a director who knows a producer who knows most of the significant actors.  That's four degrees of separation.  I know my boss who was a minor football player who knows an NFL coach who knows a world renowned football player who is married to a famous actress who knows the wife of a prince.  That's six degrees there.   I know someone who volunteers at a soup kitchen who knows a priest who knows a bishop who knows a cardinal who knows the pope.  That's five degrees.   I used to work for Tiffany & Company and knew my manager who knew the plant manager who knew the vice president of manufacturing who knew the CEO who knew Paloma Picasso who knew her father Pablo Picasso.  That's six degrees.  I knew my father who went to school with and was friends with Leonard Nimoy who knew most of Hollywood's elite or knew someone who did.  That's 3-4 degrees.  I knew my grandfather who knew a priest who knew the cardinal who knew John F. Kennedy.   I knew my neighbor who was from Dallas Texas whose Dad used to live next door to someone whose Dad was a police officer and is in that famous photo of Lee Harvey Oswald being shot to death and who knew a cop who was friends with the man who killed Oswald.  That's six degrees for one and four for the other. After seeing the movie by the same name I polled my friends, neighbors and relatives and found several knew people who knew people who had connections to famous people.  The average person knows from a few people to a few dozen and many know hundreds.  Just multiply that out a few times and you pretty much cover the globe.

The problem with the package/email tests, is that instead of going through all your contacts, you have to try and guess at which one contact is the correct direction to reach someone you don't know. Six degrees of separation does not claim that all pathways connect, only that all nodes connect. When (as noted) it's the random links between clusters that do the most work... well, trying to guess those random connections between two people you don't know is hardly a fair test of the theory.

It's one thing to choose one person one THINKS has a better chance of knowing someone. But if one could exercise each of their contacts and at each step have someone increment a counter, with some instruction to cease after some number of steps (to avoid it from becoming like chain mail, circling forever), then we could get a better feel for just how few steps there are.

Yes, social media can automate this through databases of networked people with certain connections identified. It misses people who haven't chosen to link to certain others they know on social media, and it avoids those who avoid social media. But it's becoming a rather quick way to figure out who can reach who using what pathways.

However, just because you can reach someone within 6 degrees, it doesn't mean you'll have willing participants in the middle. Some people just won't pass along a message. Secondly, for all you know, the last person that links to the person you're trying to reach might know them, but the person you are trying to reach might consider that person untrustworthy or in some way not influential or perhaps they are enemies. Thus, your message might not reach them in a good way, might even trigger opposition, or enough people in the middle might prevent them from getting a message at all.

Enjoyable video, but I found it unconvincing and it felt like you didn't consider the converse?
If there's a 10% chance (say) that the package isn't transferred at a given stage, then lower-travel-needed packages are much more likely to make it.
People primarily know people that speak the same language, so it seems like there would be a much higher distance between members of monolingual communities of different languages/continents, due to the language barrier needing to be passed before acquaintances can make long links.
The examples with fb tend to favour people who have/use fb; they tend to be more interlinked or extroverted. Similarly, fb lets you have more "friends" than relationships you can actually maintain (100-250 depending on the person; see Dunbar's number); violators contribute more.
Anecdotal evidence of being a few links from someone famous isn't meaningful either, as mentioned in the video - even though true, famous people have way more connections, so two people 4 links from a famous person can still be 7 or 8 apart.
Of course, it isn't literally true - babies know very few, there are remote tribes (possibly even isolated ones), not everyone has internet, etc.
It just feels like even though it's called "the science behind", only the supporting evidence is provided/considered, and that doesn't feel very scientific.
(Still an enjoyable and interesting video; I just feel it's not unbiased.)

In the early days of Wikipedia, there was a similar game, popular on forums. It was called Godwin's Game, after Mike Godwin and Godwin's Law.
There were two versions of the game, but the goal was the same: Find the shortest number of link clicks on Wikipedia from the starting article to the page about Adolf Hitler.

In version one, you would go on the start page of Wikipedia and click Random Article, then go from there.
In version two, you would find a keyword in someone's post, search Wikipedia for that keyword and pick the top result.

In both cases, you would post your starting article and what links you had to click to get to Adolf Hitler.

For example, searching Veritasium brings me to Derek Muller, so that is my start page.
Derek Muller -> Uranium – Twisting the Dragon's Tail -> World War II -> Adolf Hitler
2 clicks before we found the first mention of Hitler. 2 degrees of separation between this channel and the most infamous fascist dictator of all time.

The issue with the packages is the first name basis. I have 1500 friends and 1200 followers on my alternate Facebook account. By all technicalities I should be on a first name basis with at least the 1500 if not some of the 1200. But say I want to get people to take a survey that is maybe a minute long. I got 35 people to do so after messaging about 100 of my closest contacts within that circle. Getting them to sign up for a survey site was even smaller, I got 3 out of my 25 closest friends to SAY they did it. One did, according to my referral commissions. Notice how the difficulty of this challenges the strength of each bond.

By all technicalities, I am 3 degrees of separation from the president. I have a friend who is friends with the head of disability on the federal level and I can assume they are connected to the president loosely. But does that mean I could send a package to the president? Or even talk to him? Unlikely. The best chance I would have is if there was a big disability event related to that role that normal citizens can attend. Even being in that role, I am using the word connection very vaguely.

This is to say you can be connected to a lot of people. But imagine me trying to find a job through that network, time-consuming and fruitless because even if I have 100 close friends (which I feel is a fair assessment) or you use the number theorized which I think is 50 is what the brain can do. Those are the people I can theoretically ask for a favor.

The idea that even passing a message on is possible through those networks is difficult aside from social media. Which the stakes are lower so there's a small chance based on the formula of how media goes through that medium.

Fun fact, but Paul Erdős was such a prolific mathematician, publishing so many different papers with so many different people, that, there is a popular measurement in the world of science called an Erdős number, and it is a measure of degrees of separation in authorship of scientific papers between you (if you have published any such papers) and Paul Erdős. The idea of the Erdős Number actually precedes the Bacon number by several decades.

The existence of these two metrics has created a hybrid one, the Erdős–Bacon number, which represents the number of links you have with Erdős and Bacon (I believe it is the addition of them). There is also the Erdős–Bacon–Sabbath number, which is much like the former, but with the additional metric of the number of links between you and Black Sabbath.

Stephen Hawking's Erdős–Bacon–Sabbath number is 8.
Brian May's Erdős–Bacon–Sabbath number is 9.
Richard Feynman's Erdős–Bacon–Sabbath number is 10.
Carl Sagan's Erdős–Bacon–Sabbath number is 10.
Natalie Portman's Erdős–Bacon–Sabbath number is 11.
Albert Einstein's Erdős–Bacon–Sabbath number is 11.
Brian Cox's Erdős–Bacon–Sabbath number is 13.
Adam Savage's Erdős–Bacon–Sabbath number is 13.

Douglas Adam's Erdős–Bacon–Sabbath number is 14.

If we're talking just meeting people, I'm one degree from a few famous actors, which puts me two or three degrees from a lot of Hollywood. Two degrees from Jon Stewart puts me three or four degrees at most from Obama, Malala, Neil Tyson, Matt Mercer, and so many others. I've also got two degrees to George Bush Sr. It's also crazy how fast you can go into the past. IIRC, it was my great×6 uncle who made Washington surrender and sign a paper saying he caused the French and Indian War, so that means, going into the past, I probably have fewer than 6 degrees between me and George Washington. You mention that it's "comforting" near the end of the video, but I actually find it the other way around. I find makes the world feel overwhelming.

Imagine that you have a problem that has a solution, but the solution is entirely outside your grasp. It could be any problem really as long as it's one that has a solution that someone in the world might know. While you might not be able to solve this problem all you need to do is just connect with someone that knows the solution.

We know that because of the Six Degrees of Separation that we aren't far from the solution. Perhaps all you need do is ask your Aunt then your Aunt asks her friend and her friend asks her Husband and BOOM suddenly you have a solution to your problem. So you KNOW that the solution is close.

But wait, why in the world did you ask your Aunt? Perhaps you stayed in contact with a teacher from high school, and you asked them. Well, we know that your Aunt has a path to the solution, but does your old teacher? Or what if we did stick with asking our Aunt, what's to say she would think to ask her friend?

The problem is that while we know that there is a path between ourselves and anyone else that's short, what we don't have is a mapping method.

Pretty sure most of my fictional 44 friends know at least half of my other 43 fictional friends though. It's VERY clear that 7 billions is a gigantic overestimate. It's also exceedingly obvious that having one unexpected or distant link effectively doubles possibilities in just one step.
Of course, if we're talking about just everyyone we've had physical contact with, or even just people we've shared glances with, then it's a no-brainer. And I don't buy for a second the NDT argument that it's just about 'having access to people.' First of all, FB 'friendship' doesn't mean any sort of access or even that the people are going to read what you send, or that they're still on Facebook, or THAT THEY'RE EVEN STILL ALIVE.
Anyway, surprisingly pointless video :( I thought it would dig much further. The Facebook argument is essentially like saying that degrees of separation depend on having heard of someone who's heard of someone, as long as there's reciprocity at each step. It's bogus.
And finally... justifying the completely arbitrary number of 6 by pretending that noone has friends in common, or that FB counts, etc... while being illogical enough to begin with... also ignores the pivotal role that a few elite 'very famous' people play. Since, apparently, the people in the video (and referred studies) choose to believe that there's any actual meaning or comfort in the fact that you've had the most minor of interactions with anyone through 6 degrees or less, then celebrities and dignitaries travelling the world and shaking hands with countless people pretty much guarantee the fulfillment of that claim.

The package experiment was flawed. It depended on the judgment of the people sending the packages along. In the less-successful group of package handlers, being the most distant from the targets and having the least in common with them would have been less able (than the more successful group) to judge to whom to send their packages. An error in judgment anywhere in the chain could the prevent the package from coming through to the target even if a successful (but unknown) chain existed. With similar groups of people (stock brokers, doctors, attorneys, etc), errors in judgment play a lesser role because the participants' (i.e. everyone handling the packages) are more likely to send the package along to someone who is capable of maintaining the chain by chance. So we should expect people with a strong common connection (college, military service, occupation, etc.) to have more success. The connections between people who have things in common are denser, so even random jumping from one person to another could have success in getting the package to a target individual even if no previous chain between the package handlers existed.

Very interesting topic. The problem here is that "connected to" and "friends" aren't defined. As long as that's the case, "six degrees of separation" is a meaningless concept compared to 3, 4, 5, 7, 8, or 9 degrees of separation. I'm "connected to" anywhere between 3 and 3,000 people. Do relatives count? Ex girlfriends? Work colleagues? Contacts you had 20 years ago and can reach if you want to? The guy from Afghanistan at the checkout counter in the neighborhood convenience store? Case in point: Because of a coincidence, I had a chat with a famous actor, and in theory, I may be able to reach every actor in Hollywood via him, yet none of them would know who I am, and what are the odds that they would care, listen, or respond?

Path links drop rapidly but clustering remains high. I knew a guy who knew both Filipino presidential candidates Cory Aquino and Ferdinand Marcos and their extended families. This is the 'random link' that shortens the links between my clusters here in the States and the clusters in the Philippines. What I've noticed is that most of us have some pretty short links to some amazing clusters-- the real trick is knowing a bit of history and paying attention. I knew a man who knew Trotsky, Trotsky knew Lenin, Stalin, Molotov. A foreign minister for the USSR Molotov knew Hitler, Mao, etc.... I've met President Clinton's chief of staff Leon Panetta, this would link me in one degree to all of the recent presidents, candidates, and two degrees from the vast numbers of people these people would have met.... So these links are not so much random as easy to be unaware of. (In the mathematical modeling they're random, but in real life they're like most coincidences, unlikely in specifics, but common in as unspecific.

There were two separate study's done by two separate universities in the early days of the internet when email was popular but before social media caught fire. I'm thinking it was mid to late 1990's. Sorry, but I can't recall specifics. They were both American universities and I think one was Harvard but I won't swear to it. Participants were instructed to reach a given target they did not know through email using geographic location and other parameters. Anyway, it involved no such social networks as you mentioned, but was truly stranger to stranger, and the average number of people or connections required to reach the targets was between 6 and 7 people. I consider these two studies to be the most accurate and unique in an opportune time of history, because it was easy to forward emails then, spam blockers were nonexistent or very limited, junk mail had not yet gained a grip on email boxes, email was so unique that everybody was getting on board and dumping snail mail, which takes much more effort for anyone, and no formal social networks existed then to skew results . These two landmark studies could never be replicated today.

At my gifted school I was talking to one of my friends about my ancestry and then we found out that we both have great grandmothers with the same last name, but they're not the same person. The next time I visited my grandparents, I pulled out the family trees and luckily the branch in question was the longest: four greats. After some research, I concluded that we're at most eighth cousins, and possibly once removed, but I'm pretty sure it's a solid cousin number without any other crazy business. Where do we connect? 6 degrees of separation is an equilibrium constant. If for some reason a set of people(origins) has more degrees of separation, this is likely to decrease as as new social contacts have to be made in order to adapt over time. Maintaining active social contacts over years takes effort. This is why over time, some social contacts are lost because no effort is required to maintain them for social network benefits.

Comforting? Well, that's one way to look at it. It depends upon your perspective, though. There has been more research on networks like this. For instance, what if you want to change that 5 or 6 degrees of separation? What if you want to, say, control the flow of information in the network so that no new information could reach 'critical mass' and spread to the entire network? Can you do that? Is it hard? It turns out that it's actually extremely easy. Those 'weak ties'? They're weak. Which means they're fairly easy to break, and most people won't even notice. How many of those weak ties, the bridges connecting mostly-disconnected clusters, do you need to break in order to, say, drive up the minimum degrees of separation between any performer and Kevin Bacon? Well, a couple dozen broken can drive the average up into the 20s (I forget the exact numbers, but its a very small number of broken weak ties leads to large leaps as big clusters have their most efficient routes taken away).

It sure is a good thing there's no group with the ability to interfere with communication networks connected like this who are deeply invested in preserving the status quo. Such a group would be able to (quietly) virtually guarantee that no large-scale challenge to the status quo could ever gain the widespread support it needs to force a change to the established order...

This only provides evidence that the average steps to connect to someone can often, but not always, be up to 6 steps, if both agents have access to a "shared" world of contacts. If they don't, it's nonsense. Email and Facebook or social media merely reinforce this because they do operate on the premise, a priori, of a "shared access" to the same resource by both parties. The hermit without a birth certificate living as a loner nomad in the steppes of northern Mongolia is very likely way more than just six steps separated from the newborn of the third cousin of the chief of an undiscovered amazon rainforest tribe.

what qualifies as a connection? I've met my congressman, he's met the president, and let's just assume that Obama and Kevin bacon have crossed paths at some point. three degrees, maybe four. but somehow I feel like Obama wouldn't pass on a message for me as a favor to a friend of a friend-- there is no significant connection there.

when it comes to "degrees" that constitute any significant connection, my hunch is that there are probably a thousand different paths by which Ohio Joe and Jimmy Minnesota are connected, but your case for six degrees to the queen of england is a hard sell. if every person you know tried as hard as they could, and so did every person they know, and so on, the number of iterations necessary to get your package/message to the queen would certainly be higher than the number needed to find a pathway to Ohio Joe, and I think it would be more than six. any connection into the British aristocracy from outside is by its nature predisposed to be a phantom connection with no transitive value whatsoever, communicative or otherwise.

if my uncle drives prince Charles' car, for example, any claim that I am "two degrees from the royal family" is specious, illusory, and irrelevant. The prince is not engaged in any real and actual connection with my fictional uncle Adolf, and the queen would not be reading my birthday card.

This six degrees of separation becomes even more interesting when you add an element of time to it. Say for example, how many degrees are there between you and a historical figure? Obviously the further back in time the figure you are wanting to connect with the greater the number of degrees of separation. This can make it really interesting to know old people who have themselves known old people in their younger days. You may not get to experience history first hand but even so second and third hand may provide a greater degree of insight than you would get from newspapers or even history books. In my case, perhaps two decades ago now I spent some time with a man in his eighties who as a child had spent time with an older figure, allowing me to time travel a century and a half.

log(10 000 000 000) / log(50) gives 5.8, and that's all the math there is about the number 6. It means that 10 billion people with 44 friends (a few clusters and a few randoms) will present the propriety of those 6 degrees of separations.
While log(100 000 000) / log(50) yields a value of 4.7, suggesting that ppl in the us are more likely to be connected by 5 degrees of separation than 6. However it is hard for people to find the closest path to another person, just because no one knows the entire map of the interconnections between people.

While idea may sound nice for those of you who live in large countries - so there is no language or hard cultural barrier for ppl to connect to each other, view from small country is quite different. Facebook example is bad simply because there is a lot of fan pages. Lets say I have connection to U2 fan page which has a lot of members who than also have more celebrity fun pages etc. So in this example those huge celebrity pages give backbone in creation of links - not ppl knowing each other by any means. This leads us to another bad assumption in this video - 44 friends example. That example assumes that all A 44 links know 44 unknown to A links (B1-B44 links), while than every link from array of B, links to another 44 of C links and so on, where all generated links with exception to B dont have connection with A and from all other B, C, D arrays etc. My point is that there are a lot of friends lets say on Facebook who share same friends, but also there are many suggested friends - friends of our friends who are not our friends and so on. So when we speak in therms where people connect on knowing each other, clusters are very small. Someone of those sure has aunt who lives on other part of world and from her cycles someone does two - yes but 6 links to Mongolian farmer? - simply no way. Similar idea was presented by another nice channel Vsauce some time ago where author states that all people on planet are in relation to each other by fewer than 50 links - if that would be true we would not have races. All these theories come from taking one postulate from probability or statistics and building up fact theory on top of it, but both of those can not be taken for granted without an proof. When you take postulate you must stay in postulate boundaries and give yours theory as assumption not as an fact.

I think it's impossible to link to every single person on the planet, because there are certain indigenous groups that are still completely closed to the outside world. Those people may have nice networks internally, but there is absolutely no link between their cluster and the outside world.

Excluding those groups, I think the links may be even shorter than anyone knows, if you reduce your requirements for how well you must know someone to be considered linked. If you go with, say, "someone you've spoken to", that would increase everyone's personal circle of contacts tremendously. The problem is, of course, these are hard or impossible to trace, but it's the kind of thing that the CDC does to track an outbreak of an infectious disease.

The problem with this experiment is that, once you go beyond a couple degrees, there's often no way to know who would likely get the system closer to your target. The number of possible acquaintances blows up too rapidly to make a judgement unless you happen to have an obvious one.

The real way to test this would require spamming all your friends, though, so I understand why you don't want us to do that.

BTW, why no mention of the fact that this is how the Internet works--except with some extra stuff? And that you can also do this with web pages--hence the name?

It strikes me that the science of 6 degrees of separation also underlies the scam of chain letters etc (and Ponsi schemes in general). One initial investor has to find N more investors, which each have to find N more. The scheme runs out of investors quite quickly (function of N), when everyone on the network has been reached - and the scheme collapses.

This theory was actually tested earlier this year in a Swedish tv-show called "Around the world in six steps". It's about two Swedish tv-personalities who were dropped off somewhere in the world with the mission to connect with a specific person through six other people.
In the first episode they were dropped off in the countryside of Bolivia with the mission to connect with a famous Swedish author. They made it in 7 steps.
In the second episode they were dropped off in the countryside of Nepal with the mission to connect with Gordon Ramsey. They made it in 6 steps.
In the third episode they were dropped off in the countryside of Senegal with the mission to connect with Buzz Aldrin and here too, they made it in 6 steps.

The actual number of degrees of separation probably depends on outliers anyway. Anthropologists, diplomats and missionaries already serve as the bridge that reaches different cultures- 3 degrees on each side of the border should hit just about everyone.

But are there any ways a linear relationship could be forced in practice out there? As an example, 10 people live in a series of rooms. They interact with the room on either side of them, but never 2 doors down. The person in the last room would take 10 degrees of separation just to get outside the building. Yeah, there probably isn't any literal series of rooms in real life, but there may be some situations where geography or culture forces an extra degree or two beyond the average.

a few years ago I moved to Brazil and studied at an American school there. When I was talking to my friends we were looking at an old year book from last year. In the year book was a girl named "Jen", who left right before I arrived. One year and a half later she came back to the school and I met her, but we were never very close. By default it is literally impossible for everyone in the world to be 'connected' as there are undoubtedly millions of people with close to no "friends" or "acquaintances" or even literally none.

A hypothetical example would be an old hermit that has been in seclusion since becoming orphaned at a young age; people who knew about the hermit beforehand have passed away and no new connections have formed after they entered seclusion.

As a result there are no longer any connections to people who have physically (or otherwise) met the hermit.

There are potentially no other people that even know of the hermit's existence unless the people who had met him told someone else before passing away, provided the people they told remembered the information.

I no longer believe this is true as its based on a much lower population, it started during a time when the world had less than half the population and now it can only be held close to still being true via virtual connections that are only online. These are not real connections as you may as well say people are connected if they eat the same products or watch the same TV shows. It isn't real, hell, people were actively friending anyone on Facebook for bragging rights, to show off that number.Then you have to factor in those that live in small towns, farming communities that have near no contact with the outside world. Or how about those in unindustrialized 3rd world nations? How about the "uncontacted" tribes around the world? There are over two dozen so called "lost tribes" that are still living like its the stone ages and there are laws in place to prevent people from contacting them.6 degrees of separation is a nice distraction, something that can make the world feel smaller...or you bigger. That is all it is, its still false.

As a computer networking student your experiment is very interesting.  It really does not test what the shortest path is, but rather it tests our routing techniques.  In networking you often have very short and efficient pathways between networks, but when a routing table is messed up it becomes very easy for devices very close together to completely lose access to each other.Point being, there may be only 4-6 links between people... but that sadly does not mean that we will ever find those routes.I'd love to see a follow-up video on the concepts of different ways we 'value' routes to unknown destinations.  Do people value popularity? Resourcefulness? People with unique ties?  It would be very interesting to see what values were successful vs not.

I think the whole "E-mail this to someone who you think knows Derek is kind of silly. It doesn't fully model the 6 degrees problem for two main reasons:

1 people are lazy. A lot of chains that could have made it to Derek will be stopped by people not re-sending the message.
2 people aren't smart (at least not omnipotent). It is entirely possible Derek and I are connected by 6 degrees, but the chance that I and the people I choose all pick the perfect person to forward it to in the least number of steps is miniscule. In order to truly model the problem, we would have to send the email out to everyone we know and have them send it to everyone they know etc to account for all possible chains of connections. I bet a lot of those would make it to Derek but only a few would do it in under 6 steps

The buttons and thread remind me of Metatron's cube.  Where the centers of 13 circles ( all same diameter ) are connected via straight lines from one center point to the other twelve center points. So each center point is connected to every other center point. The arrangement of the circles is like a hexagonal snowflake. One circle in the center is surrounded by twelve circles. There are six sets of two circles whose centers are in line with each other and are 60 degrees from the next set clockwise and anticlockwise.  As seen in Spirit Science episode 6 on youtube, you can visual many shapes using Metatron's cube: merkaba, dodecahedron, icosahedron, hexagon, cube, equilateral triangle, tetrahedron, rectangle, square, star shapes...etc.

Aside from a penchant I seem to have for bumping into people I know far away from where I know them, I have noticed quite often that friends of mine are also friends with other friends of mine whom they know through completely different avenues. I am quite certain that the Internet has accelerated this, though I began noticing it long before the era of social media.

A more recent example: I have a second cousin whom I only know (so far) through Facebook. It turns out that she is also friends with two friends of mine whom I do know in real life. I know these two mutual friends through different, albeit related, avenues - one via a listserv and one via a mutual friend - but they do not know each other. My cousin knows each of them through totally different avenues, although all four of us share a common interest.

I'm also only three degrees of separation from Kevin Bacon, though that has not changed in over 20 years.

One thing that bothered me about six-degrees discussions is that the definition of a "connection" is not always clear.  Is "lived in the same city" a connection?  What if the "city" is just a very small town?  What about the Sentinelese?  The Sentinelese are a remote group that has consistently rejected contact with the modern world (look it up).  That group might break the six-degrees rule under common definitions of "connected" such as friendships, close relatives, or co-workers.  You can probably still make it work, however, if you consider all of the Sentinelese to be connected because they're from the same group, and then consider the modern fishermen who were killed when they landed on a Sentinelese-controlled island to be connected to the entire Sentinelese group, and then connect the fishermen to their relatives and friends in the normal manner.  My point here is not so much about remote tribes as it is about definitions.  I'd feel more comfortable talking about "The Science of Six Degrees" if the definitions were more clearly measurable.

Great video, great experiment.  No doubt Derek is aware of one degree of separation between his experimental plan, and the  shortest path between two people. In fact, that would be another very interesting bit of research- to somehow compare the actual optimum path with what people are able to discover.

There is a few problem to this assumption. The modelling with the strings is that the cross over intersect, but in connection, the 2 cross over links are not intersecting.

There is also another issue from some tests did:
1. There are dead-links. For some reasons they are isolated, or they are unwilling to be connected or relaying information.
2. There are cyclical links as well, which means the links are not used to connect further, but connected back. This is a form of clustering of which many people do not have connections out of their ethnic group or religious groups.

It actually makes sense to forward the message you want to send through someone who knows a person, that knows a person, that knows a person who knows the one you actually want to get to. It's because if - for example - you wanted to message Kevin Bacon, it would be practically impossible that he'd actually get that (he probably gets like a hundred tweets, messages, e-mails per minute). But if you somehow got to his agent, or someone he sees on a regular basis, you'd be almost sure that he got the actual content of the message.

One thing I wondered about that package experiment, and might have to do with its success rate, it doesn't seem to take into account the possiblity of human judgement mistakes, basically, when you send the package to boston (or email towards you), you don't necessarily know which of you acquaintances will have the best chance of being connected to the target.

Imagine it like this: I want to get that mail to you, my first thought is a friend who lives in the same city as you, a no brainer, but what I didn't know when I chose him to get the message to you is that my aunt was actually classmates and best friends with your mother, and thus would have gotten to you much faster, while my friend just happens to live in the same large city and has no connection at all.

Not to mention there's the possibility of needless loops, basically the second or third person could unknowingly send the message to someone the first person in the line already knew themselves, thus wasting several links (which becomes increasingly likely with each link)

I'm not actually going to bother the people I know with this, but I think it shouldn't be too hard to find a path to Derek through academia. I'd just find a professor at my school who had ties to a professor at the university of Sydney. Then, odds are I know a professor who knows that one, and odds are the one at Sydney knows another professor there who knows Derek, since that's where he completed his PhD (he also completed his B.S. at Queen's, so that's another good choice).
So I'm confident I could reach him with a total string of at most 6 people if you include myself and Derek, which is 5 degrees of separation (likely 2 fewer than that since my background is in Physics). Add one extra step to that for anyone who hasn't gone to a large University to contact a friend of their who has, and that's a method for six degrees that would work for most people.

This closely parallels a nifty little game I've been hooked on lately, and you can find it on Apple Apps store: the Wiki game.

Basically your goal is to get form a randomly picked article to a second article (either also randomly picked or, just for fun, the article "Jesus"), but only through the hyperlinks in the page. This can usually be completed within about 7 links. To get to the "Jesus" article, the added constraint is that you have to do it within 5 links, but this is surprisingly doable.

Another game mode is to get to a second random article without using the "United States" article, which relates to the "strength of weak ties", since the "United States" article has weak ties to so many other articles that it becomes a real challenge if that particular article is banned.

Anyways, great video as always, and I might just go try out that challenge of yours.

The problem with the experiment is that you have no way to tell how is actually more close to another random person.
For exaple, I may send an e-mail to a friend who actually has more steps he needs to do in order to arrive to you.
The six degrees of separation connects two people in six steps or less, but it "knows" all the connections before hand.
So as simply a game, it's nice, but it can not prove the theory unless everyone involved successed in doing so

So this video, and more specifically the Fine Brother's new show, gave me an idea for a little game. 

STEP 1: Go to Wikipedia
STEP 2: Clear your browsing history (or at least anything to do with Wikipedia)
STEP 3: Click "Random Article"
STEP 4: Click the first link in the article that is prat of the actually article, ergo, not anything in italics before the article and not the pronunciation.
STEP 5: Repeat step 4 until you either hit a loop (the first link will be purple rather than blue) or you hit a dead end (there is no link in the article)
STEP 6: Go to your browsing history and count how many articles you made it to.

My record is 31 articles. It is really quite interesting to see all the different things you go through. I once started at a random train station and hit things like US Government, Theory of Mind, Science its self. You never know where you will end up.

Awesome video, even though you should have talked a little bit about Barabasi's model, which can describe the power law distribution of the degree (a fundamental feature of real networks a.k.a. scale free property).

I think the results of your experiment will be inconclusive. Not because of connectedness, but because of participation. If the few random weak ties do not participate, those edges are removed from the network and it becomes a clustered network with high diameter.

For example, I am in academia at the moment and I met a person who is currently in physics in Australia, roughly your age (who might have a higher chance of knowing someone who have met you). If he decides to ignore my mail, that promising link is broken, increasing the diameter. Still, it would be interesting to see the results of the few mails you do get ;)

I've had some strange small world experiences. Like I have this friend named Jim. He had been helping me with ham radio for years and particularly got me into using 220Mhz ham band. Well I bought a 220Mhz handheld transceiver and probably a month later went on a trip to San Juan Island in Washington. First time I turned on the radio I decided to look to see if any repeaters were in the area that used it. I saw one and called out to see if anyone was listening. The repeater operator came back. It was pretty cool using a band I had never used before (doesn't sound too cool to anyone reading, but it was to me). We talked for probably a half of an hour and I ended up talking about my friend Jim. Note that I was over 800 miles from home where he lived. And he said "Jim? I know Jim. I used to work with him years ago." I got a good laugh out of it, that over 800 miles away from home, I ran into someone on a radio band that not a lot of people use that happened to know the person who got me into that band in the first place.

While the idea of 6 degrees (or 5 degrees) of separation for everyone on Earth is generally sound, this doesn't account for extremely isolated populations (e.g. Pitcairn Island, remote Inuit communities, etc...) whose networks may only have a small handful of outside connections to nearly equally isolated networks.  The most extreme example of this of course are so-called "uncontacted peoples" (e.g. Sentinelese people), whose networks are completely isolated from the rest of the globe.  So no matter how ubiquitous Facebook has become, you cannot reach everyone on the globe through 5-6 connections.

As we all can understand an email test (like the package test, explained in your videos) can easily take a wrong path and never end up at the destination! In fact, such a thing doesn't mean that a six degrees of separation theory exist but that the “package” didn’t follow the shortest path (the 6 degrees of separation states that the MINIMUM you need is 6 people). Also if you want to make things works faster in your email experiment, it will be smarter if you propose to send an email not to one of our friends but at 20 friends or more. In such a way some packages may arrive and some of them might not. So those who will, can confirm if the minimum you need is 6 (or less) or more!

Remember in order for your system to work out you need at least five individuals to make the right choice which is unlikely to happen!

I think that some of these experiments are hindered by a willingness barrier. For example, I know that my third cousin knows some pretty efamous youtube personalities, and I'm 98% confident that I could get an email to Veritasium, if - and this is the kicker - if, every person along that chain is willing to bother the next person 'up' as it were.

I am skeptical that is the case, however. Just because my cousin has rubbed elbows with a youtube personality, doesn't mean that she is necessarily going to be willing to 'use' that relationship for something trivial. And even if she does, the next person may not be willing to 'use' their relationship either.

There's a social capital economy at work that makes this hard to do even when the connections exist. Which is a little sad, I suppose. But nonetheless, a failure for an email to reach its destination may not be for a lack of connections.

How do you talk about Erdos and degrees of separation and not mention the Erdos number?!

The short of it is that Erdos was a phenomenally prolific mathematician that loved working with everyone on anything; he is thought to be the most prolific author in mathematical history, per Wikipedia and their source. He became popular at conferences for his willingness and ability to quickly contribute to problems his colleagues were working on. It got to the point that mathematicians began to track the number of connections it took to get them to Erdos via coauthors, known as their Erdos number. This phenomenon is so pervasive that the AMS's publication and review database MathSciNet has a tool to compute collaboration distance, with a button to 'Use Erdos' as the second author automatically. Most mathematicians I've talked to have at least some idea what their Erdos number is.

Sadly, as I have thus far only published my dissertation, my Erdos number is undefined. If you count my advisor as a coauthor, my number would be at worst 5.

I guess the problem here is that you can't know which of your friends has "the closest way" to you. For example I have like 400 "friends" on Facebook. So it should totally possible to reach you within six steps. But it is not only really hard for me to choose the right one out of 400 people but also for the next person to choose again the one out of 400. I guess the chance to get the right people six times in a row is extremely small. Imho the best way would be some sort of computer program that checks the connections between people on Facebook or whatever and shows you how much steps are between two persons. Actually the german business network Xing uses this. So if you go on the profile of a stranger you see like "Xy knows zy and he knows you" or something in that regard.

This is kinda how the Gnutella network works, you know, the one that was used by Limewire and similar programs. You only connect to a few other nodes an ask all of them for the file you are looking for. They ask the nodes they are connected to and eventually you hopefully find a node which has the file, which then initiates a connection with you.
